intro: Epilobium watsonii var. parishii, commonly known as the Parish's willowherb, is a flowering plant native to western North America. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. The plant features slender, erect stems with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. Its showy pink to purple flowers appear in clusters at the ends of the stems, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. The species is characterized by its morphological variation and is often found in association with other members of the Onagraceae family.
